intro: Clastopus vestitus var. eriocarpus, commonly known as the hairy-fruited clastopus, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers that are clustered in umbels, typical of the family. Its fruits are distinctive, covered in a dense layer of fine hairs, giving it the varietal name "eriocarpus," meaning "hairy fruit." This plant thrives in dry, rocky soils and is often found in open woodlands and sagebrush habitats.
